awd_titl_txt: Bio-nanomanufacturing of Protein Therapeutics Using Membrane Microfluidics
awd_abstract_narration:
The market for therapeutic proteins is valued near $140 billion annually. Many of these therapeutics are glycoproteins, which require the addition of specific sugars, called 'glycans' at an exact position on the protein through a process called protein glycosylation. The glycan affects protein folding and function and ensures it retains its therapeutic potency. In nature, glycoproteins are produced through a series of sequential reactions inside a cell. Making therapeutic glycoproteins within cells is challenging for a variety of reasons, and extensive and costly purification steps are required to harvest the therapeutic material. With this award, a cell-free glycosylation network will be constructed in a microfluidic device that separates reactions in space and time, giving supreme flexibility in optimizing individual reactions and constructing glycans with high specificity. The benefits of this manufacturing paradigm to society are reducing the cost of these drugs and providing scientists an avenue to design and develop synthetic drug compounds that may or may not exist in nature to treat disease. The related education plan creates a hands-on bio-nanomanufacturing activity for a high school girls organized by the PIs and their student trainees, so that young women will understand the power of biotechnology and be inspired to pursue these career paths. 

Cell-free protein synthesis holds great promise for producing high-value, biotherapeutic nanomaterials without cell culture and benefitting from chemical manufacturing know-how. Here, raw materials and biological enzymes are mixed to produce biological products. Shortcomings of this approach are competing reactions, side products, and low yields. Cells avoid these shortcomings by localizing reactions within subcellular compartments and orchestrating the reaction sequences. The biocatalysts that give the final molecule its essential posttranslational features are compartmentalized in membranes. Handling enzymes outside of their native lipid environment can drastically reduce their activity. Thus, in vitro, sequential, bio-enzymatic reactions have never been achieved in a cell-free manner. The research objective is to mimic the elegant compartmentalization strategies used by cells in a microfluidic biomembrane device that organizes biological reactions in proper spatial and temporal sequence. These devices will generate authentically glycosylated proteins. Through assessment of nanostructure product architectures, this work will advance understanding of nanoscale phenomena and processes for nanomaterials manufacture and discovery. This cell-free device concept will enable facile optimization of glycosylated protein production, and provide a framework for understanding how experimental conditions affect product yield and quality that is broadly applicable to the bio-nanomanufacturing of virtually any posttranslationally-modified protein.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The overall goal of the proposed research was to mimic using a microfluidic biomembrane device the elegant organelle compartmentalization strategies used by cells to organize biological reactions in proper spatial and temporal sequence to produce proteins and decorate them with sugar groups called glycans. These devices generate authentically glycosylated proteins by reproducing the biological processes on chip that lead to the same posttranslational modifications occuring inside cells. This cell-free chip concept enables facile optimization of glycosylated protein production, and provides a framework for understanding how experimental conditions affect product yield and quality that is broadly applicable to the bio-nanomanufacturing of virtually any posttranslationally-modified protein. Given that the market for therapeutic proteins is valued near $140 billion annually, and many of these therapeutics are glycoproteins, this cell-free protein synthesis approach holds great promise for producing high-value, biotherapeutic nanomaterials without cell culture and benefitting from chemical manufacturing know-how.

The objectives of this project were: 1) Develop a microfluidic biomembrane platform for cell-free protein synthesis by sequential enzymatic reactions; 2) Elucidate how lipid scaffold and environmental conditions affect enzyme activities; and 3) Quantify how dynamic changes in residence time determine product quality. To achieve these objectives, we created microfluidic channels patterned with supported lipid bilayers that present necessary glycosyltransferase enzymes in a specific order and process flow. We devised methods for cell-free proteins synthesis on chip, the transfer or a glycan to it, and the process to isolate our product from the reaction mixture using three unit operations designed into three sequential chips. These unit operation chip devices were used to generate authentically glycosylated proteins through designer multi-step, compartmentalized reactions.

The intellectual merit of this research is the creation of a first-in-kind microfluidic platform that permits sequential protein synthesis and glycosylation reactions and the efficient formation of properly glycosylated proteins. The open nature of this cell-free device concept enables facile optimization of glycosylated protein production, and provides a framework for understanding how environmental conditions and lipid scaffold (i.e., transport and diffusion mechanisms at the nanoscale) affect final product yield and quality. This platform is a first, important step towards the biosynthesis of high-value therapeutic antibodies, and the groundwork forged here should be broadly applicable to the biomanufacturing of many posttranslationally-modified proteins. By expanding the range of products that can be derived from cell-free protein synthesis to include glycoconjugates, we open an avenue to transform how glycosylated protein therapeutics are manufactured.

The broader impacts of this research are gaining an innovative platform that achieves sequential glycosylation of proteins and can be used to optimize conditions of production. This strategy is general and may be applicable to any posttranslational target (given the sequence of enzymes are known) including those for non-therapeutic uses or high-value, unnatural biochemical products. The advantage of designing this platform in a microfluidic chip is precise control of fluid and environmental conditions, intermediate products can be used to fuel downstream reactions, and other unit operations can be easily integrated, thereby expanding applications of the device beyond manufacturing in the future. With decreasing chip cost, the platform will expand from a process optimization tool to mid-scale production device. Given that glycosylation is a major challenge in the manufacture of human protein drugs, this device and approach should assist further development of cell-free processes to produce these targets.  

The educational broader impact inspired by this research was the development of a laboratory module on biomanufacturing for outreach events for high school girls organized by the PI and students. This activity achieved several outcomes: 1) fosters rural tenth-grade girls’ interest in STEM fields and life science; 2) educates their parents about career options for their daughters in biotechnology; and 3) gives leadership and teaching opportunities to graduate students. It has directly impacted 50+ high school students and their families from the rural upstate NY area in the period of this grant. In that same period, 20+ graduate students (men and women) participated in organizing and executing the outreach activity.

 


Last Modified: 11/27/2021
Modified by: Susan Daniel
